block.p: Lycos Agrees to Be Bought By Spanish Telephone Giant Lycos, the big Internet portal, agreed to be bought by Terra Networks, the Internet unit of the Spanish telephone giant Telefonica, for $12.5 billion in stock.

The companies said the combination, which also includes a partnership with the German media conglomerate Bertelsmann, would create the first truly global Internet company with operations in 37 countries. [Page C4.]

Robert J. Davis, the self-described driven chief executive of Lycos, lives by a couple of mottos. ''You let up, you lose,'' is one. ''Speed is life'' is another. The Boss. [C8.]

Profit Up 6.5% at Hewlett-Packard Hewlett-Packard posted a 6.5 percent increase in operating profit, exceeding Wall Street estimates. The company cited strong sales of personal computers and Unix servers used on corporate networks and the Internet. Revenue from continuing operations grew 15 percent. Before the company announced its results, its shares closed at $140, up $6. [C10.]

Cybersleuths Pursue Net Criminals A growing number of Internet habitues have turned into cybersleuths, and their work has become vital to the pursuit of online criminals. In the spirit of members of a neighborhood watch program, they point law enforcement officials to leads. And some have escalated their role from tipster to sleuth, accumulating evidence to identify actual suspects including malicious hackers, virus writers and online child pornographers. [A1.]

Stocks Hold Gains After Fed Action Stocks held onto early gains after the Federal Reserve announced its sixth interest-rate increase since last June. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 126.79 points, or 1.2 percent, to 10,934.57. Broader stock indicators also closed higher. The Nasdaq composite index climbed 109.92 points, or 3.1 percent, to 3,717.57, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 13.68 points, to 1,466.04. [C10.]

Investors Assail BMW's Rover Deal A week after BMW agreed to pay a British group more than $750 million to take over the German automaker's money-losing Rover subsidiary, angry investors accused BMW's top management of amateurism, arrogance, bad judgment and deceptive statements. And in a blunt rebuttal to aspiring buyers, the controlling Quandt family announced that it had ''not the slightest interest in selling'' and is ''100 percent committed to BMW.'' [C3.]

Mining Company Chief to Step Down Anglo American, the world's largest mining company, announced that Julian Ogilvie Thompson, the last of a generation of managers who dominated the South African-led company during and beyond the apartheid era, would step down as chief executive. [C3.]

U.P.I. Reporter Resigns Abruptly Helen Thomas, a White House reporter since John F. Kennedy was president, abruptly resigned from United Press International, one day after the news service was acquired by News World Communications, which was founded by the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, leader of the Unification Church. Ms. Thomas, who is 79, broke into journalism in 1943 as a radio writer for the news service, took over the White House beat in 1961 and became the unofficial dean of White House reporters. [A18.]

Consumer Prices Unchanged in April Consumer prices were unchanged in April and the construction of new homes rose, government figures showed, signaling that the economy was expanding with little to no inflation. The flat Consumer Price Index came after a 0.7 percent jump in March and was the first report since last June's to show no change. [C25.]

House Backs Bill to Ban Web Fees The House unanimously endorsed a bill that would prohibit federal fees on Internet access in a move to put to rest longstanding rumors of pending Internet e-mail taxes. [C25.]
